revision.comment: added [[Category:Crown Princes of Saudi Arabia]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Sultana bint Abdulaziz Al Saud}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox royalty | type = | name = Sultan bin Abdulaziz Al Saud
سلطان بن عبد العزيز آل سعود | native name = سلطان بن عبدالعزيز آل سعود | title =[[Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia]] | titletext = | more = | image = Prince_Sultan.jpg | alt = | caption = Crown Prince Sultan bin Abdulaziz Al Saud |succession1 = [[Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia]]
First Deputy Prime Minister |reign1 = 1 August 2005 – 22 October 2011 |reign-type1 = Tenure |reg-type1 = Monarch |regent1 = [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|Abdullah]] |predecessor1 = [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|Abdullah]] |successor1= [[Nayef, Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia|Nayef]] |succession2 = [[Council of Ministers of Saudi Arabia|Second Deputy Prime Minister]] |reign2 = 13 June 1982 – 1 August 2005 |reign-type2 = Tenure |reg-type2 = Monarch |regent2 = [[Fahd of Saudi Arabia|Fahd]] |predecessor2 = [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|Abdullah]] |successor2 = [[Nayef, Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia|Nayef]] |succession3 = [[Armed Forces of Saudi Arabia|Minister of Defense and Aviation and Inspector General]] |reign3 = 22 October 1963 – 22 October 2011 |reign-type3 = Tenure |reg-type3 = Monarch |regent3 = {{List collapsed|title=''See list''|1= [[Saud of Saudi Arabia|Saud]]
[[Faisal of Saudi Arabia|Faisal]]
[[Khalid of Saudi Arabia|Khalid]]
[[Fahd of Saudi Arabia|Fahd]]
[[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|Abdullah]]}} |predecessor3 = [[Muhammed bin Saud Al Saud|Muhammed bin Saud]] |successor3 = [[Salman bin Abdul Aziz|Salman]] |deputy3 = [[Turki II bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud|Turki II]]
[[Abdul-Rahman bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud|Abdul Rahman]] |succession4 = [[Riyadh Province|Prince of Riyadh Province]] |reign4 = 22 February 1947 – 24 December 1953 |reign-type4 = Tenure |reg-type4 = Monarch |regent4 = [[Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia|Abdulaziz]]
[[Saud of Saudi Arabia|Saud]] |predecessor4 = [[Nasser bin Abdulaziz|Nasser]] |successor4= [[Nayef, Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia|Nayef]] | spouse = | spouse-type = | issue = {{List collapsed|title=''See list''|1=[[Bandar bin Sultan]]
[[Khalid bin Sultan]]
[[Turki bin Sultan]]
[[Nayef bin Sultan]]
[[Salman bin Sultan]]
''Badr bin Sultan''
''Mohammed bin Sultan''
''Saud bin Sultan''
''Ahmad bin Sultan''
''Nawwaf bin Sultan''
''Abdullah bin Sultan''
''Mishaal bin Sultan''
''Mansour bin Sultan''
''Fawwaz bin Sultan''
''Abdulmajid bin Sultan''
''Abdul Ilah bin Sultan''}} | issue-link = | issue-pipe = | full name = Sultan bin Abdulaziz bin Abdul Rahman bin Faisal bin Turki bin Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Saud | Nickname = Sultan of good | house = [[House of Saud]] | father = [[Ibn Saud|King Abdulaziz]] | mother = [[Hassa bint Ahmed Al Sudairi]] | birth_date = 1925 | death_date = 22 October {{Death year and age|2011|1925}} | birth_place = [[Riyadh]], [[Kingdom of Nejd and Hejaz]] | death_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States|U.S.]] | burial_date = 25 October 2011 | burial_place = [[Al Oud cemetery]], Riyadh | signature = | religion = [[Islam]] }} {{Contains Arabic text}} '''Sultan bin Abdulaziz Al Saud''' (1925 – 22 October 2011) ({{lang-ar|سلطان بن عبدالعزيز آل سعود}}), called ''Sultan al-Khair'' ({{lang-ar|سلطان الخير}}, ''Sultan of goodness'') in [[Saudi Arabia]],{{cite news|title=The Dream of Gerontocracy|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Succession.-a0272258958|accessdate=28 March 2013|work=The Weekly Middle East Reporter|date=29 October 2011}} was the Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia from 2005 to 2011. ==Early life and education== Sultan was born in [[Riyadh|Riyadh, Najd Sultanate]] in 1925. He was the 12th son of [[King Abdulaziz]]{{cite journal|last=Mouline|first=Nabil|title=Power and generational transition in Saudi Arabia|journal=Critique internationale|date=April–June 2012|volume=46|pages=1–22|url=http://www.ceri-sciencespo.com/publica/critique/46/ci46_nm.pdf|accessdate=24 April 2012}} and his mother was [[Hassa bint Ahmed Al Sudairi]].{{cite book|author=Winberg Chai|title=Saudi Arabia: A Modern Reader|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lh4bENPP_HEC&pg=PA193|accessdate=26 February 2013|date=22 September 2005|publisher=University Press|isbn=978-0-88093-859-4|page=193}} He was the second of the [[Sudairi Seven]].{{cite news|last=Shenk|first=Mark|title=Oil Surges to Record as King Fahd's Death Raises Supply Concern|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&refer=home&sid=apDJnl7svZqo|accessdate=4 March 2013|work=Bloomberg|date=1 August 2005}}{{cite news|title=The Political Leadership - King Fahd|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/SAUDI+ARABIA+-+The+Political+Leadership+-+King+Fahd.-a057816188|accessdate=16 March 2013|work=APS Review Gas Market Trends|date=29 November 1999}} Prince Sultan, along with many of his brothers, received his early education in religion, modern culture, and diplomacy at the royal court.{{cite journal|author=Sultan bin Salman Al Saud|title=Supporting Peace, Justice and Equality|journal=Presidents and Prime Ministers|date=March 2001|volume=10|issue=2|page=16|url=http://www.questia.com/read/1G1-75373145/supporting-peace-justice-equality|accessdate=31 August 2013}} {{Subscription required|via=Questia}} ==Early experience== His career in public service began in 1940 when he was made a deputy to then [[Riyadh]] governor or emir, [[Nasser bin Abdulaziz|Prince Nasser]]. In 1947, Prince Sultan replaced Prince Nasser as governor of Riyadh.{{cite book|author=George Kheirallah|title=Arabia Reborn|date=1952|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|location=Albuquerque|page=254|url=https://www.questia.com/read/682471/arabia-reborn|accessdate=14 March 2015}}{{Subscription required|via=Questia}} Prince Sultan also assisted King Abdulaziz's attempts to establish a national administrative system based on the Islamic Sharia law during this period. In 1947, Prince Sultan oversaw [[Aramco|ARAMCO's]] construction of the Kingdom's rail link between [[Dammam]] and Riyadh. He was appointed as the kingdom’s first minister of agriculture in 1953 and minister of transport in 1955.{{cite news|title=Crown Prince Sultan’s Death Starts Plan for Saudi Succession|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-11-01/crown-prince-sultan-s-death-starts-plan-for-saudi-succession.html|accessdate=13 April 2012|work=Bloomberg Businessweek|date=1 November 2011|author1=Glen Carey|author2=Vivian Salama}} Although his direct military experience was brief, heading the Royal Guard in Riyadh in the early 1950s, he felt a lifelong connection to the military and the cause of Saudi independence from an early age. Major General [[Carl von Horn (1903–1989)|Carl von Horn]], Swedish commander of the UN observer mission during the [[North Yemen Civil War|Yemeni civil war]], described the Prince Sultan as "a volatile and emotional young man" in the early days. ==Minister of Defense and Aviation== In 1963, [[Faisal of Saudi Arabia|Crown Prince Faisal]] appointed Prince Sultan as minister of defense and aviation.{{cite news|title=Veteran Saudi defence minister becomes heir to throne|url=http://www.lebanonwire.com/0805/05080121AFP.asp|accessdate=1 February 2013|work=Lebanonwire|date=1 August 2005|location=Riyadh}} He presided over the development of the [[Military of Saudi Arabia|Saudi armed forces]]. During the reign of King Faisal, Prince Sultan was particularly interested in [[Yemen]].{{cite book|author1=P. Edward Haley|author2=Lewis W. Snider|author3=M. Graeme Bannerman|title=Lebanon in Crisis: Participants and Issues|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mdrqhFpLkC8C&pg=PR9|accessdate=16 October 2012|year=1979|publisher=Syracuse University Press|isbn=978-0-8156-2210-9|page=9}} His influence declined under the reign of [[King Khalid]]. Sultan purchased U.S. tanks, fighter planes, missiles and [[Boeing E-3 Sentry|AWACS]] (airborne warning and control systems). However, as a result of problems assimilating technology within its armed forces, a relatively high proportion of the military equipment is stored or under maintenance, despite a large portion of Saudi's $34 billion defense budget being spent on maintaining military equipment. Sultan allegedly became extraordinarily wealthy from kickbacks by Western businesses that handled multibillion-dollar defense contracts.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2002/12/22/magazine/the-way-we-live-now-12-22-02-primer-who-s-who-in-the-house-of-saud.html?pagewanted=2|title=The way we live now|newspaper=The New York Times|date=22 December 2002|accessdate=9 December 2010}} He was involved in many scandals, including [[Al-Yamamah arms deal|the Al Yamamah deal]].{{cite news |url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20101121/wl_mideast_afp/saudipoliticsroyalshealth;_ylt=Ak7X8By.biX9Wemgf9e76MgLewgF;_ylu=X3oDMTMwNTk5N3VsBGFzc2V0A2FmcC8yMDEwMTEyMS9zYXVkaXBvbGl0aWNzcm95YWxzaGVhbHRoBHBvcwM2BHNlYwN5bl9wYWdpbmF0ZV9zdW1tYXJ5X2xpc3QEc2xrA3NhdWRpa2luZ3RvdQ--|title=Saudi king to US for treatment of back ailment|date=21 November 2010|work=Yahoo! News|accessdate=9 December 2010}} However, his influence remained unhindered until his health began to deteriorate. During his tenure, Saudi Arabia became the largest importer of U.S. arms. He was a strong proponent of U.S.-Saudi partnership.{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2002/0812/p09s02-coop.html|title=Backlash in Saudi Arabia|author=Nawaf Obaid|date=12 August 2002|work=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=9 December 2010}} As well, Sultan authorized a deal with the [[British Aircraft Corporation]] (BAC) in 1965. His program, called ''Operation Magic Carpet'', traded [[£]]16 million for six second-hand [[English Electric Lightning|Lightnings]], six [[Hawker Hunter]]s, and a set of missile launchers going to [[Royal Saudi Air Force]]. Geoffrey Edwards served as the official intermediary. British pilots also came over, privately contracted. Prince Sultan was an expert on the Yemen civil war and Soviet involvement in the [[Horn of Africa]] in 1985.{{cite news|url=http://image.guardian.co.uk/sys-files/Politics/documents/2006/10/27/PJ5_39BriefforThatcherSept85.pdf|format=PDF|title=Briefing for the Prime Minister's meeting with Prince Sultan|date=25 September 1985|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=9 December 2010 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vf9BP28b|archivedate=11 January 2011|deadurl=no|location=London}} In 1996, Prince Sultan opposed Pentagon plans to relocate U.S. troops to safer locations after the [[Dhahran]] complex bombings.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2yBIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KYEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6015,6300009&dq=prince+sultan+minister+of+defense&hl=en|title=Saudi Arabia – Defense Minister opposes U.S. plans to move soldiers|work=The Vindicator|date=15 July 1996|accessdate=9 December 2010}} He visited [[Iran]] in May 1999 that was the first official visit of a Saudi minister since 1979.{{cite book|author=Anthony H. Cordesman|title=Saudi Arabia Enters the Twenty-First Century: The Political, Foreign Policy, Economic, and Energy Dimensions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DCVicuT7kCMC&pg=PR5|accessdate=29 September 2012|date=1 April 2003|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-275-97998-0|page=5}} ==Second Deputy Prime Minister== On 13 June 1982, after the death of [[King Khalid]] and Crown Prince Fahd became the King, Prince Sultan was appointed second deputy prime minister.{{cite news|title=Crown Prince Fahd takes control of largest oil-exporting nation|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1876&dat=19820614&id=E4osAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5M4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6176,3067260|accessdate=28 July 2012|newspaper=Herald Journal|date=14 June 1982}} Opposition to his appointment as second deputy prime minister came in particular from two half brothers, Musaid and [[Bandar bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud|Bandar]], both of whom, like [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|Abdullah]], were born in 1923 and therefore, were older than Prince Sultan, who was born in 1925. The objection of Prince Musaid was easily ignored since his son, [[Faisal bin Musaid]], had assassinated King Faisal. However, the interests of Bandar bin Abdulaziz were much harder to ignore. Thus, he was compensated and the dispute was resolved.{{cite journal|author=Simon Henderson|title=After King Abdullah. Succession in Saudi Arabia|journal=Policy Focus|date=August 2009|volume=96|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/pubPDFs/PolicyFocus96.pdf}} Prince Sultan, in December 1995, attempted to seize power through the support of the Ulema when Crown Prince Abdullah was in Oman for a summit of [[Gulf Cooperation Council|the Gulf Cooperation Council]].{{cite journal|author=Paul Michael Wihbey|title=Succession in Saudi Arabia: The not so Silent Struggle|journal=IASPS Research Papers in Strategy|date=July 1997|issue=4|url=http://www.iasps.org/strategic4/SA.htm}} However, his attempted coup failed. ==Crown Prince== {{Infobox hrhstyles |royal name = Crown Prince Sultan bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud |image = [[Image:Coat of arms of Saudi Arabia.svg|70px]] |dipstyle = [[His Royal Highness]]{{cite web|title=Council of Ministers: Membership|url=http://www.saudiembassy.net/about/Biographies-of-Ministers.aspx|work=Royal Embassy of Saudi Arabia, Washington, DC|accessdate=10 June 2011}} |offstyle = Your Royal Highness |altstyle = }} On 1 August 2005, Sultan bin Abdulaziz was designated [[heir apparent]] despite having a discord with King Abdullah.Leyne, Jon. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4735505.stm Tensions remain among Saudi royals], ''BBC News'', 1 August 2005. Retrieved 7 December 2008. During the same period he led the group called Sudairi Seven, being the eldest of the group after King Fahd's demise.{{cite news|author=William Safire|title=The Split in the Saudi Royal Family|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/12/opinion/the-split-in-the-saudi-royal-family.html|accessdate=13 April 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=12 September 2002}} ==Various positions== Prince Sultan was Saudi Arabia's [[inspector general|Inspector General]]. He was chairman of the board of Saudi Arabia's national airline, [[Saudi Arabian Airlines]]. As chairman, he approved a ban on smoking inside all Saudi airports.{{cite news|url=http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article164086.ece|title=Kingdom bans smoking at airports|author=Fatima Sidiya|newspaper=Arab News|date=19 October 2010|accessdate=9 December 2010}} In 1986, he founded the Saudi National Commission for Wildlife Conservation.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3766919.stm|title=Profile: Saudi Prince Sultan|first=Gerald|last=Butt|date=3 June 2004|work=BBC|accessdate=9 December 2010}} He was chairman of the Higher Council for Islamic Affairs, which financially supports Muslim communities around the world.{{cite news|title=Profile: Saudi Prince Sultan|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4734609.stm|accessdate=1 February 2013|work=BBC|date=1 August 2005}}{{cite news|title=Who's who: Senior Saudis|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7068977.stm|accessdate=27 April 2012|work=BBC|date=30 October 2007}} ===Scientific prizes sponsored by Prince Sultan bin Abdulaziz=== * Prince Sultan bin Abdulaziz prize for water. He was the founder and patron of the [[Prince Sultan bin Abdul-Aziz International Prize for Water]], a bi-annual international scientific award for water research created in 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.psipw.org/about.html|title=About the Prize|publisher=PSIPW|accessdate=31 December 2008}}{{cite journal|title=HRH Prince Sultan: Environmentalist and Art Patron|journal=Oasis Magazine|date=Winter 2009–2010|url=http://www.oasis-mag.com/the-magazine/issues/winter-20092010/hrh-prince-sultan-environmentalist-and-art-patron|accessdate=19 July 2013}} * Prince Sultan bin Abdulaziz Chair for environmental engineering, department of civil engineering, [[King Fahd University]] for Petroleum and Minerals. It is the first chair in the university. * The scientific agreement between Prince Sultan bin Abdulaziz and [[Oxford University]] for academic and cultural co-operation, which enables Saudi students for bachelor, master and PHD degrees in the field of human sciences.{{cite web|title=Biography. Prince Sultan bin Abdulaziz bin Abdulrahman bin Faisal Al Saud|url=http://www.ittaleem.com/showthread.php?t=224254|work=iTTaleem|accessdate=31 March 2012}} ==Charity works== A non-profit charity organization, [[Sultan bin Abdulaziz Al Saud Foundation]], was set up and funded by Prince Sultan in 1995 for social objectives. The foundation includes the following centers in different countries: *Sultan Bin Abdulaziz Humanitarian City{{cite web|title=Sultan bin Abdulaziz Humatarian City|url=http://www.humanitariancity.org.sa/|publisher=Sultan bin Abdulaziz Humatarian City|accessdate=31 March 2012}}{{cite web |url= http://www.eurosynapses.eu/index.php/saudi-arabia/item/4-sultan-bin-abdulaziz-humanitarian-city|title=Sultan bin Abdulaziz Humanitarian City (SBAHC)|work=Euro Synapses|accessdate=29 August 2012}} **Sultan Bin Abdulaziz Science and Technology Center **Charity housing projects **Sultan Bin Abdulaziz Special Education Program at the [[Arabian Gulf University]] in Bahrain **Prince Sultan Center for Speech and Hearing in [[Bahrain]] **King Abdulaziz Center for Islamic Studies at [[Bologna University]] **Sultan Bin Abdulaziz Arab and Islamic Studies Program at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] *Prince Sultan Bin Abdulaziz Private: Committee for Relief. This private committee organizes relief and medical convoys and sets up camps to combat diseases like Malaria and blindness. It has carried out several developmental, social and medical projects, like, digging wells, building schools, public libraries, mosques, hospitals, establishing dialysis centers. It also sponsors Muslim preachers in [[Ethiopia]], Chad, [[Niger]], Malawi, [[Mali]], [[Comoro Islands]], [[Djibouti]] and [[Indonesia]]. ==Controversy== In 2002, families of the victims of the [[September 11 attacks]] in the United States sued Prince Sultan and other senior Saudi officials for their alleged contributions to [[al-Qaeda]] linked charities.{{cite news|title=Veteran Saudi defence minister becomes heir to throne|url=http://www.lebanonwire.com/0805/05080121AFP.asp|accessdate=12 April 2013|work=Lebanonwire|date=1 August 2005|agency=AFP|location=Riyadh}} The lawsuits were thrown out by a US federal judge due to insufficient evidence submitted. ===Donations=== In April 2005, Sultan donated £2 million to the [[Ashmolean Museum]]. This is regarded as one of the most controversial donations [[Oxford University]] received. A year after his donations to establish an art museum, Oxford University agreed to 'expedite' the scholarship application process for Saudi students, and identify colleges for ten Saudi students from [[Prince Sultan University]] (PSU). When this arrangement became public, it led to criticism from both academics and students stating that it was no academic worth to the university, bypassing Oxford’s governing council, and breaching the admissions process for prospective students.{{cite web|last=Simcox|first=Robin|title=A Degree of Influence|url=http://w.socialcohesion.co.uk/files/1301651125_1.pdf|publisher=The Centre for Social Cohesion|accessdate=22 April 2012|year=2009}} A press release issued by Oxford University on 20 April 2005 said that:
HRH Prince Sultan bin Abdulaziz Al Saud has given the Ashmolean Museum a substantial donation to provide a fitting home for the Museum's internationally renowned collection of Islamic art. The total value of the gift is £2 million, which will also provide for ten scholarships at the University of Oxford for Saudi Arabian students.
The press release added further that ‘the new gallery, part of the ambitious redevelopment of one of the world’s oldest museums, will be named the “Prince Sultan bin Abdulaziz al Saud Gallery”’. ''[[Arab News]]'' on 21 April 2005 reported that Sultan’s donation was a ‘move to promote understanding between Islam and the West’, adding that ‘Saudi and British officials’ had said that the new gallery ‘will help to portray Islamic culture and civilization in right perspectives.’ ==Personal life== Prince Sultan had thirty-two children by his multiple wives. His eldest son [[Khalid bin Sultan]], after Prince Sultan's death, was appointed deputy minister of defense and served in the post until 20 April 2013.{{cite news|title=Saudi deputy defence minister Prince Khalid Bin Sultan replaced|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/saudi-arabia/saudi-deputy-defence-minister-prince-khalid-bin-sultan-replaced-1.1172889|accessdate=20 April 2013|newspaper=Gulf News|date=20 April 2013|agency=Reuters}} [[Bandar bin Sultan]] was the secretary general of [[National Security Council (Saudi Arabia)|the national security council]] between 2005 and January 2015, and the former head of [[Al Mukhabarat Al A'amah|the general intelligency directorate]]. [[Fahd bin Sultan]] is the governor of [[Tabuk Province|the Tabuk province]]. [[Salman bin Sultan]], another son, is the former deputy defense minister.{{cite news|title=Son of former Saudi crown prince named deputy defence minister|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/08/06/uk-saudi-defence-idUKBRE97513S20130806|accessdate=7 August 2013|work=Reuters|date=6 August 2013}} Faisal bin Sultan (born 1951) is the secretary general of Sultan bin Abdulaziz Al Saud foundation.{{cite web|title=Sultan bin Abdulaziz al Saud Foundation sponsors Arab Creativity Award Ceremony|url=http://www.ameinfo.com/174676.html|work=AMEINFO|accessdate=31 March 2012}}{{cite book|author=Sabri Sharif|title=The House of Saud in Commerce: A Study of Royal Entrepreneurship in Saudi Arabia,|year=2001|publisher=I. S. Publication|location=New Delhi|isbn=81-901254-0-0|url=https://books.google.com/?id=51Bb8Ix7xw8C&pg=PA151&lpg=PA151&dq=hala+bint+ahmad+al-sudairi#v=onepage&q=hala%20bint%20ahmad%20al-sudairi&f=false}} His other sons are [[Turki bin Sultan|Turki]] (1959–2012), Nayef (born 1979), Badr (born 1980), Mohammed, Saud, Ahmad, Nawwaf, Abdullah, Mishaal, Mansour, Fawwaz, Abdulmajid and Abdul Ilah. Prince Sultan had fifteen daughters, the oldest of whom is Nawf bint Sultan.{{cite news|author=Abdullah Al Oreifij|title=‘He is a father to every Saudi’|url=http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentID=2009121256802|accessdate=29 December 2012|newspaper=Saudi Gazette|date=12 December 2009|location=Riyadh}} One of his daughters, Reema, is married to [[Muhammad bin Nayef]], son of the late Crown Prince [[Nayef bin Abdulaziz]].{{cite news|title=Time, surely, for a much younger one|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21534829|accessdate=26 April 2012|work=The Economist|date=29 October 2011}} His other daughter, Noura bint Sultan, is married to [[Turki bin Nasser]]. Another daughter, Munira bint Sultan, who was late [[Faisal Bin Fahd Bin Abdul Aziz|Faisal bin Fahd]]'s spouse and died in June 2011 at age 59.{{cite news|title=Rulers offer condolences to Prince Sultan bin Abdulaziz|url=http://www.wam.org.ae/servlet/Satellite?c=WamLocEnews&cid=1289993935448&pagename=WAM%2FWamLocEnews%2FWAM_E_ArticleMailClient&parent=Collection&parentid=1135099399983|accessdate=6 May 2012|work=WAM Emirates News Agency|date=11 June 2011}}{{cite news|title=Prince Sattam performs funerary prayers over the deceased|url=http://www.ainalyaqeen.com/arch_2011/June-17/en5.php|accessdate=12 February 2013|work=Ain Alyaqeen|date=17 June 2011}} ===Wives=== * Munira bint Abdulaziz bin Musaed bin Jalawi (deceased), mother of Khalid, Fahd, Faisal and Turki{{cite news|title=Wife of Saudi crown prince dies in Paris hospital|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2011/Aug-25/Wife-of-Saudi-crown-prince-dies-in-Paris-hospital.ashx#axzz1rBrO3Wvf|accessdate=5 April 2012|newspaper=The Daily Star Lebanon|date=25 August 2011}} * Huda bint Abdullah Al Shaikh, mother of Saud, Nayef, Nawwaf, Badr * Areej bint Salem Al Maree, mother of his youngest two sons, Abdulmajid and Abdul Ilah * Hussa bint Muhammed bin Abdulaziz bin Turki (divorced), mother of Princess Daad * Jowaher bint Mohammed bin Saud bin Nasser Al Farhan Al Saud (divorced) * Mouda bint Saud Al Kabeer Al Saud (divorced) * Mounira bint Mishaal bin Saud Al Rashid (deceased) * Leila Al Thunayan (sister of [[Iffat Al-Thunayan|Iffat Al Thunayan]]) (divorced){{cite book|author=As'ad AbuKhalil|title=The Battle for Saudi Arabia. Royalty, fundamntalizm and global power|year=2004|publisher=Seven Stories Press|location=New York City|isbn=1-58322-610-9|url=https://books.google.com/?id=lfU5ldbBOasC&pg=PA9&dq=abdul+illah+bin+abdulaziz+and+saudi+succession#v=o}} * Mouda bint Salman Al Mandeel Al Khaldi (divorced) * Dina bint Abdulhamid Alsahhaf (divorced) * Maha bint Abdullah Al Binyan (divorced) * Abir bint Fahd Al Faisal Al Farhan Al Saud (divorced), mother of Fawwaz * Ghadir bint Shawaan Al Shibani (divorced) ==Characteristics== Prince Sultan was regarded{{By whom|date=August 2012}} as a workaholic .He doled out money at banquets in keeping with tribal custom. A conservative, it was expected that he would have put a brake on [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|Abdullah]]'s timid reforms, if he had become king, he was considered to be pro-American.{{cite news|last=Penketh|first=Anne|title=Succession at House of Saud: The men who would be king|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/succession-at-house-of-saud-the-men-who-would-be-king-848505.html|accessdate=13 April 2012|newspaper=The Independent|date=17 June 2008}} ==Views== Sultan took a lifetime [[anti-communist]] and [[anti-Soviet]] view, based on his dislike of Soviet [[state atheism]] as well as Soviet interest in Gulf oil and access to ports that he felt risked Saudi independence. He rebuked U.S. President [[Jimmy Carter]] for what he saw as "pusillanimity" in the face of the [[Soviet invasion of Afghanistan]].{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/politics-obituaries/8844666/Crown-Prince-Sultan-Ibn-Abdul-Aziz-al-Saud.html|title=Crown Prince Sultan Ibn Abdul-Aziz al Saud|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=25 October 2011|date=23 October 2011|location=London}} In a 23 October 2001 interview in Kuwaiti newspaper ''As Seyassa'', concerning [[9/11]] attacks, Sultan stated “Who stands behind this terrorism and who carried out this complicated and carefully planned terrorist operation? Osama bin Laden and those with him have said what indicates that they stand behind this carefully planned act. We, in turn, ask: Are bin Laden and his supporters the only ones behind what happened or is there another power with advanced technical expertise that acted with them?”.{{cite journal|last=Dudney|first=Robert S.|title=Verbatim Special: War on Terror|journal=Air Force Magazine|date=December 2001|pages=40–48|url=http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Documents/2001/December%202001/1201verb.pdf|accessdate=22 April 2012}} ==Wealth and property== Prince Sultan’s wealth in 1990 was reported to be $1.2 billion.{{cite news|title=The billionaires 1990|url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/1990/09/10/73983/|accessdate=15 August 2012|work=CNN/Fortune|date=10 September 1990}} Later, his fortune was estimated at $270 billion, which he distributed between his sons prior to his death in October 2011 in order to support their political position in the competitive princely arena.{{cite web|last=Yamani|first=Mai|title=Saudi Arabia’s Old Regime Grows Older|url=http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/saudi-arabia-s-old-regime-grows-older|publisher=Project Syndicate|accessdate=23 April 2012|date=25 October 2011}}{{cite news|last=Riedel|first=Bruce|title=What to Expect from the New Saudi Crown Prince|url=http://nationalinterest.org/commentary/what-expect-the-new-saudi-crown-prince-6107|accessdate=23 April 2012|work=National Interest|date=1 November 2011}} Prince Sultan owned [[2–8a Rutland Gate]], the former London residence of the Lebanese politician and businessman [[Rafic Hariri]]. Prince Sultan had been gifted the property after Hariri's assassination in 2005.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d6f7ea5a-fcca-11e1-9dd2-00144feabdc0.html|title=Hyde Park mansion on sale for £300 million|author=Ed Hammond and Sally Gainsbury|date=12 September 2012|work=The Financial Times|accessdate=28 October 2015}} ==Health issues== Prince Sultan was rumored to have had colon cancer in 2003. A foreign correspondent was forced to leave the country after reporting his health problems.{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/templateC05.php?CID=3153|title=Saudi Royals Reunited? Crown Prince Sultan Returns Home|first=Simon|last=Henderson|date=11 December 2009|publisher=The Washington Institute|accessdate=9 December 2010}} In 2004, Prince Sultan was diagnosed with [[colon cancer]] and underwent several corrective surgeries. He underwent an operation to remove an intestinal polyp in [[Jeddah]] in 2005.{{cite news|title=Saudi heir to throne dies in hospital|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2011/10/22/saudi-crown-prince-saud-dies.html|accessdate=29 July 2012|work=CBC|date=22 October 2011|agency=AP}} Prince Sultan visited a Swiss clinic in late April 2008.{{cite news|last=Hammond|first=Andrew|title=Saudi prince health signals possible power clash|url=http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/?id=25776|accessdate=11 February 2013|work=Middle East Online|date=7 May 2008|location=Riyadh}} In April 2009, he began to suffer from [[Alzheimer's disease]].{{cite news|url=http://arabia2day.com/featured/crown-prince-sultan-/|title=Crown Prince Sultan Suffers from Alzheimers|date=1 February 2011|work=Arabia Today|accessdate=18 October 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/18291511|title=The royal house is rattled too|date=3 March 2011|work=The Economist|accessdate=18 October 2011}} A leaked March 2009 diplomatic cable from [[WikiLeaks]] stated that U.S. diplomats viewed Prince Sultan as "for all intents and purposes incapacitated".{{cite journal|last=Fraker|title=Scenesetter for Senator Bond's April 6–8 visit to Saudi Arabia|id={{WikiLeaks cable|09RIYADH496}}|publisher=[[WikiLeaks]]|date=31 March 2009|url =http://wikileaks.ch/cable/2009/03/09RIYADH496.html|accessdate=11 January 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vf8hWnAq|archivedate=11 January 2011|deadurl=no}} He was possibly suffering dementia, specifically Alzheimer's disease.{{cite web|last=Henderson|first=Simon|title=Saudi Arabia's Oil Policy Vacancies|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/saudi-arabias-oil-policy-vacancies|publisher=The Washington Institute|accessdate=27 May 2012|date=7 January 2011}} ===Morocco vacation=== In February 2009, Sultan spent several months in New York City at [[New York–Presbyterian Hospital]] and underwent surgery in New York. He then convalesced at [[Agadir]], Morocco. He went back to Saudi Arabia, but soon returned to Morocco in August 2009. During his vacation, the Saudi cabinet increased officer salaries, a traditional domain of Sultan.{{cite news|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/displayarticle.asp?xfile=data/middleeast/2010/October/middleeast_October446.xml§ion=middleeast&col|title=Saudi crown prince in good health, on holiday|date=27 October 2010|agency=Reuters|newspaper=Khaleej Times|accessdate=9 December 2010}} In 2009, King Abdullah took charge of all defense purchases and reduced the power of the Defense Ministry. In October 2010, Abdullah personally conducted much of the negotiations for the U.S. arms package worth over $60 billion.{{cite news|url=http://www.officialwire.com/main.php?action=posted_news&rid=245784&catid=855|title=For Saudis, U.S. Arms Deal is a Challenge|date=26 October 2010|work=iWireNews ™ (iWireNews ™ and OfficialWire)|accessdate=9 December 2010}} In November 2010, Sultan received Lebanese Prime Minister [[Saad Al-Hariri]] to discuss the future of Lebanon's government.{{cite news|url=http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article179739.ece|title=Sultan receives Hariri in Agadir|newspaper=Arab News|date=4 November 2010|accessdate=9 December 2010}} He had been receiving treatment since 2009 for what analysts and diplomats believed to be cancer.{{cite web |url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20101121/wl_mideast_afp/saudipoliticsroyalshealth;_ylt=Ak7X8By.biX9Wemgf9e76MgLewgF;_ylu=X3oDMTMwNTk5N3VsBGFzc2V0A2FmcC8yMDEwMTEyMS9zYXVkaXBvbGl0aWNzcm95YWxzaGVhbHRoBHBvcwM2BHNlYwN5bl9wYWdpbmF0ZV9zdW1tYXJ5X2xpc3QEc2xrA3NhdWRpa2luZ3RvdQ--|title=Saudi king to US for treatment of back ailment|date=21 November 2010|work=Yahoo! News|accessdate=9 December 2010}} At the end of November 2010, he returned to Saudi Arabia because King Abdullah had left for the United States for surgery. His return was seen as a legal formality necessary under Saudi law, which stipulates that only one of the kingdom's top two officials can be abroad at a given time.{{cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703567304575628223064983984.html|title=Saudi King to Seek Medical Care in U.S.|author=Summer Said and Margaret Coker|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=9 December 2010|date=22 November 2010}} ==Death and funeral== The Saudi Royal court announced on 22 October 2011 that Prince Sultan died at dawn of an unspecified illness.{{cite news|url= http://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/23/world/middleeast/prince-sultan-bin-abdel-aziz-of-saudi-arabia-dies.html?pagewanted=all|title=Prince Sultan bin Abdel Aziz of Saudi Arabia Dies|newspaper=The New York Times|location=New York|issn=0362-4331|accessdate=29 August 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/10/22/saudi-arabias-crown-prince-sultan-bin-abdul-aziz-al-saud-has-died/|title=Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Sultan bin Abdulaziz Al Saud Dies|work=Fox News|accessdate=26 June 2012}} According to media reports, Prince Sultan had been battling cancer and had been seeking medical treatment in the United States since mid-June 2011.{{cite news|last=McDowall|first=Angus|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/22/us-saudi-arabia-sultan-idUSTRE79L0DL20111022|title=Saudi Crown Prince dies: royal court|newspaper=Reuters|date=22 October 2011|accessdate=22 October 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-15413275|title=Saudi Arabian Crown Prince Sultan dies|work=BBC|date= 22 October 2011|accessdate=22 October 2011}} He had a surgical operation in New York in July 2011.{{cite news|title=Funeral held for Crown Prince Sultan|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-15451009|accessdate=29 July 2012|work=BBC|date=25 October 2011}} Unnamed U.S. officials cited by ''[[The New York Times]]'' stated that he died at [[New York-Presbyterian Hospital]] in [[Manhattan]].{{cite news |first=Neil|last=MacFarquhar|title=Prince Sultan bin Abdulaziz of Saudi Arabia Dies|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/23/world/middleeast/prince-sultan-bin-abdel-aziz-of-saudi-arabia-dies.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=22 October 2011|accessdate=24 October 2011}} His body was taken from New York City to Riyadh on 24 October 2011. His funeral was held at the Imam Turki bin Abdullah mosque in [[Riyadh]] on 25 October 2011 in the presence of King Abdullah bin Abdulaziz. He was buried in [[Al-Oud cemetery|Al Oud cemetery]] in Riyadh.{{cite news|last=Shaheen|first=Abdul Nabi|title=Sultan will have simple burial at Al Oud cemetery|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/saudi-arabia/sultan-will-have-simple-burial-at-al-oud-cemetery-1.916706|accessdate=29 July 2012|newspaper=Gulf News|date=23 October 2011}} Various leaders, including the president of Afghanistan, [[Farouk al-Sharaa|Farouk Al Sharaa]], the then vice-president of Syria, the Iranian foreign minister and the head of Egypt's ruling military council, participated in the funeral. Additionally, other statesmen went to Riyadh to offer their condolences, such as the US Vice President [[Joe Biden]], Pakistani President [[Asif Ali Zardari]] and Malaysian Prime Minister [[Najib Razak]].{{cite news|title=Saudi Arabia holds funeral of Crown Prince Sultan|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/10/25/173562.html|accessdate=29 July 2012|work=Al Arabiya|date=25 October 2011}} ==Honours== Among others, Prince Sultan was the recipient of the following honours and medals: * [[File:Ordre national du Tchad - Grand Croix.svg|50px]] [[National Order of Chad]], First Class (1972). * [[File:SEN Order of the Lion - Grand Cross BAR.png|50px]] [[Order of the Lion of Senegal]] (1972). * [[File:Cordone di gran Croce OMRI BAR.svg|50px]] [[Order of Merit of the Italian Republic]], First Class (19/07/1997).[http://www.quirinale.it/elementi/DettaglioOnorificenze.aspx?decorato=11786 Quirinale website] * [[File:Spange des König-Abdulaziz-Ordens.png|50px]] [[Order of Abdulaziz Al Saud]] (1973; First Class).{{cite news|title=Head of King Khalid Award announces names of winners|url=http://www.ainalyaqeen.com/arch_2011/nov-25/en5.php|accessdate=20 July 2013|work=Ain Alyaqeen|date=25 November 2011}} * [[File:Ordre national du Merite GO ribbon.svg|50px]] [[National Order of Merit (France)|National Order of Merit]] (1973; Grand Class). * [[File:VEN Order of the Liberator - Grand Cordon BAR.png|50px]] [[Order of the Liberator]], First Class (Venezuela, 1975). * {{flagu|Malaysia}} : Honorary Grand Commander of the [[Order of the Defender of the Realm]] (2000){{cite web |url=http://www.istiadat.gov.my/index.php/component/semakanlantikanskp/|title=Semakan Penerima Darjah Kebesaran, Bintang dan Pingat Persekutuan.}} He was also posthumously given the King Khalid award in 2011. ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel top|width=100%}}
